awd_titl_txt: Transfer Initiative for Engineering Scholars (TIES) - Phase II
awd_abstract_narration:
The Transfer Initiative for Engineering Scholars (TIES) project will increase opportunities for academically talented, 2- and 4- year students with financial need to transfer to programs in electrical or computer engineering at the Georgia Institute of Technology. The PI team will retain many of the strategies that were used in a first implementation of TIES; however, these have been further refined and will move TIES to a best practices blueprint for recruiting and retaining these transfer students. This project will address two of the major challenges faced by academically gifted students who are strong candidates for admission: financial need and academic support. The target population for this effort will include students at community colleges, and 2- and 4- year institutions that serve underrepresented groups.  Approximately 115 scholarships will be award to 33 students over the five-year grant period. The TIES support structure will enable these students to perform at or above the level of traditional students. Since many of the TIES scholars will maintain strong ties to their home institutions, they can serve as role models and help create a pipeline for community college graduates who want to attend Georgia Tech or other top engineering programs.

The TIES program will be based on an analysis of successful paths taken by non-traditional students and generalizing them for a broader group of institutions.  Using an approach and management team that have had success in a variety of outreach efforts for improving engineering enrollment and diversity, the PIs will build and expand upon those existing efforts to offer several support program options for such students and will include a mix of programs designed specifically for non-traditional junior-level transfers. Examination of these combinations of students and programs will advance the understanding of how to help non-traditional students. Several program details, such as active involvement with a cohesive student cohort and mentoring activities focused on research and career development, will keep students motivated to succeed.  TIES will address important national and institutional concerns by providing financially limited students from 2- and 4- year colleges opportunities to graduate from a top-tier engineering school. This program will provide a best practices template for other departments and engineering schools that wish to recruit and graduate talented non-traditional students.

por.por_cntn:
The Transfer Initiative for Engineering Scholars (TIES) program was created to address the financial and academic challenges of transfer students from 2- and 4- year schools to a larger top-tier engineering university. TIES provided academic and financial support for transfer students to the School of Electrical and Computer Engineering at the Georgia Institute of Technology from 2014-2020.   Financial support of up to $10,000 per academic year was offered to accepted transfer students who demonstrated financial need.  In addition to financial support, TIES provided: (1) faculty mentorship for student academic success, (2) seminars and events for helping participants identify options such as paid internships, coops and undergraduate research positions to lessen ongoing financial pressures, (3) a 1-credit hour course designed specifically for transfer students during their first semester that used ECE material to teach essential study skills.  The TIES support structure enabled participants to perform at or above the level of traditional transfer students in terms of GPA as well as the speed with which they were able to become aware of acclimate to the environment and resources available at Georgia Tech.  In all, TIES provided support for 38 transfer students.  Of all TIES students, 24 graduated, 7 remained active at the time of this reporting, and 6 were not retained in the program (4 changed majors and 2 were not retained at Georgia Tech.)  TIES also represented a diverse pool of students with 48% from under-represented minorities including 29% women (both numbers higher than the average representation Institute).

In the first three years, TIES provided up to 2.5 years of support for each cohort.  However, TIES shifted to one-year scholarships to allow for a greater number of students receiving funding.  Along with this transition, TIES increased partnerships with existing programs in the school that provided seminars, career guidance, research opportunities, and mentoring to help students stay connected beyond the one-year program.   COVID impacted funding distribution in the final year, however, TIES functioned as an integral part of the support structure for transfer student during its project period.  The outcomes emphasized the importance and benefits of continual and intentional efforts to help transfer students connect in new academic environments.

 

 


Last Modified: 01/26/2022
Modified by: Elliot Moore
por.por_txt_cntn:
The Transfer Initiative for Engineering Scholars (TIES) program was created to address the financial and academic challenges of transfer students from 2- and 4- year schools to a larger top-tier engineering university. TIES provided academic and financial support for transfer students to the School of Electrical and Computer Engineering at the Georgia Institute of Technology from 2014-2020.   Financial support of up to $10,000 per academic year was offered to accepted transfer students who demonstrated financial need.  In addition to financial support, TIES provided: (1) faculty mentorship for student academic success, (2) seminars and events for helping participants identify options such as paid internships, coops and undergraduate research positions to lessen ongoing financial pressures, (3) a 1-credit hour course designed specifically for transfer students during their first semester that used ECE material to teach essential study skills.  The TIES support structure enabled participants to perform at or above the level of traditional transfer students in terms of GPA as well as the speed with which they were able to become aware of acclimate to the environment and resources available at Georgia Tech.  In all, TIES provided support for 38 transfer students.  Of all TIES students, 24 graduated, 7 remained active at the time of this reporting, and 6 were not retained in the program (4 changed majors and 2 were not retained at Georgia Tech.)  TIES also represented a diverse pool of students with 48% from under-represented minorities including 29% women (both numbers higher than the average representation Institute).

In the first three years, TIES provided up to 2.5 years of support for each cohort.  However, TIES shifted to one-year scholarships to allow for a greater number of students receiving funding.  Along with this transition, TIES increased partnerships with existing programs in the school that provided seminars, career guidance, research opportunities, and mentoring to help students stay connected beyond the one-year program.   COVID impacted funding distribution in the final year, however, TIES functioned as an integral part of the support structure for transfer student during its project period.  The outcomes emphasized the importance and benefits of continual and intentional efforts to help transfer students connect in new academic environments.
